title.narrative: F.a: Adivasi community forest rights follow up (National Adivasi Alliance south zone)

description.narrative: The Forest Rights Act (FRA-2006) recognized the Adivasis rights over the forest lands, cultural rights and the right to manage forest resources. It created a mechanism to establish individual and community rights. While in the Southern Zone (Karnataka, Ker ala, Tamil Nadu) like the rest of India, there has been some success in establishing individual rights (IFR), recognition of community rights (CFR) has lagged. These rights are critical to maintaining cultural identity and establishing a sustainable econom ic resource base. In recent past there has been some legal and policy initiatives, which have put the community rights related implementation of FRA 2006 at risk. The CAF Act, formerly known as Compensatory Afforestation Management and Planning Authority ( CAMPA), and the draft national forest policy (2018) threaten to strip Adivasi communities throughout India of ownership of the forest. In direct violation of the FRA these laws would allow for the establishment of plantations on Adivasi lands and the wides pread extraction of forest resources by multi-national corporations. This project builds upon earlier projects, and is designed to protect and promote the traditional, customary cultural and environmental rights of indigenous people, and the sustainable ma nagement of forest resources for the forest dwellers own economic empowerment and cultural identity. This project focuses on South Indias three states i.e. Karnataka, Tamil Nadu and Kerala as well as Jharkhand. It will assist Adivasi communities to fully t ake ownership of the forest by providing trainings to increase their capacity to understand the threats posed by the CAF Act and the draft national forest policy, the importance of claiming community rights as means of protecting the forest, maintaining cu ltural identity, and establishing a sustainable economic resource base, empower the village councils (Gram Sabhas) to manage forest resources at the local level, and to assert their rights at the local, state, and national levels. This project will build s kills to manage and protect the forest through organic farming techniques and the sustainable harvesting, processing, managing, and value addition of minor forest products (MFP). Through the alliance zonal and national meetings this project will raise awar eness of current threats, develop and implement strategies to counter them, and identify resources that will sustain the movement for Adivasi rights over time.
